title: Connecting Wavelengths, Colors and Astronomical Objects

contents.content: Below are three different images of M3 made using different filters, chromatic ordering sequences, and color balances. Note how these images look compared to your image of M33.

images.altText: Three different filtered images of M33.
images.figText:
Three different images of M33 have been made using different combinations of filters and color balancing.

Left image:
Combined infrared and ultraviolet image of M33. Credit: Spitzer/GALEX data, NASA/JPL-Caltech

Center image:
Collective image of M33 obtained with the contributions of: Paolo Demaria, Giuseppe Donatiello (composition and processing), Marco Favuzzi, Terenzio Fusco, Rolando Ligustri, Alessandro Elio Milani, Zlatko Orbanic, Andrea Pistocchini, and Tim Stone. Creative Commons CCO 1.0.

Right image:
Image of M33 by Francesco Antonucci, Creative Commons 4.0 international.

question.labelPre:
The sentence below comes from the NASA/JPL-Caltech information page and describes what is seen in the far left image. The sentence identifies three different objects that are listed in order based on the wavelength of the light they emit from shortest to longest. Since this is a chromatically ordered image, choose the correct color to fill in the blanks in the sentence below:

Far-ultraviolet light from young stars glimmers
near-ultraviolet light from intermediate age stars glows
and dust rich in organic molecules burns
